properties.name: A Distant Inspiration
properties.description: Posted by DeisnormanilaWhen I was 18, my mother told me the story of a father and an aunt. The father had gifts of charm and dance. The aunt was Miss Philipines just before my birth. At one time, the pageant banner was housed with us. Recently I came across a website about Vida Doria, Miss Photogenic Miss Universe 1971 and smiled about the relationship between her and the press. Perhaps one day we will swap our stories.

properties.name: Deer Park Apartments
properties.description: Posted by Deisnor 819 county street, taunton, maLived here for a couple of years around age 9. Found memories of low income "luxury apartments" which included a jacuzzi that never worked and pool which never had a water BUT there were windows everywhere and sliding doors onto the balcony. In the winter the snowplows would push all the snow to the end of the complex to create giant snow mountains which all the kids tunneled through to create igloos. There was also a basketball court and I remember learning to play HORSE with the neighborkid, Israel. Good fun.

properties.name: Former Home Early 70s
properties.description: Posted by Trygger bartlett terrace, brockton, maWhere I saw my mom crying about the death of Elvis and jumped out of windows onto old mattresses and thought older boys were gross for making forts so they could look at porn. And most importantly got my first albums which included Shawn Cassidy, Blondie, Planet Rock and The Message/Grand Master Flash and The Furious Five. Still the music that this place really inspires is REO Speedwagon.

properties.name: Hotel Di-Ann
properties.description: Posted by Deisnor I stayed here when I first arrived in Amsterdam January 1994. We became friends and when I left, my name stayed behind. Thanks guys. While still a budget hotel, it is significantly nicer now. Stay there, eat candy, say hi!

properties.name: KBG
properties.description: Posted by Jason on the KattenBurgerGracht: An inredibly lucky find. We just wanted to get out of Broek en Waterland as soon as possible, we wanted to move that week. But in Amsterdam, people put their apartments on the rental market months before they are even ready to start moving out, so this was the only vacant place i saw that could be occupied right away. It had been vacant for a months, asking too much, we just offered them less, and they accepted (the dutch people we told this to had never ever heard of such a thing). Once we moved in, we realized it was basically a young family commune. The building turned out to be an old police station covnerted into condos just 3 years prior. It filled up immediatly with 10 new couples, who all proceeded to make babies. So there were 9 young kids, and in fact, every kid born in those years was a boy. Tabor was no exception, he officially became part of the Kattenburgergracht Futbal Club on St. Patty\'s Day, 2004, born right there in the apartment, under the stark exposed beams. Most of the units in the building had open door attitudes, and packs of young kids would run from one home to the next, leaving a trail of speeletjes, hagelslag, appelstroop, and dikkesaap. We built a little playspace with padded climbing area, and a sort of slide that the kids would rampage on. The building shares a little park in the rear with a few other buildings (college dorms and other apartment buildings) with a playground and a meticulously cared for array of flora that stays green and lush all year round. Riding into the back courtyard from the street in the winter is a transformation from grey stone gritty old europe to a modern fresh light green alive new nation. It was paradise. The apartment was a very euro, super modern, minimalist loft like place, but with cozy carpet filled bedrooms upstairs. The windows and balcony looks out over 2 converging canals, the neighbors had boats. The open kitchen with island mounted stovetop made cooking a supremely social activity, especially when in need of advice on how to really make the pindasaus just right. The only downers: too many stairs with kids and groceries, no closets in the whole place, it was such a fancy place that we ended up ruining it (kids), and it was haunted, sorta.
